Graphical abstract The state-of-the-art synthetic strategies, characterization techniques and advances of MOF-based SACs for batteries have been summarized with current issues, promising ideas and prospects. The next-generation energy storage systems such as fuel cells, metal-air batteries, and alkali metal (Li, Na)-chalcogen (S, Se) batteries have received increasing attention owing to their high energy density and low cost. However, one of the main obstacles of these systems is the poor reaction kinetics in the involved chemical reactions. Therefore, it is essential to incorporate suitable and efficient catalysts into the cell. These years, single-atom catalysts (SACs) are emerging as a frontier in catalysis due to their maximum atom efficiency and unique reaction selectivity. For SACs fabrication, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been confirmed as promising templates or precursors due to their high metal loadings, structural adjustability, porosity, and tailorable catalytic site. In this review, we summarize effective strategies for fabricating SACs by MOFs with corresponding advanced characterization techniques and illustrate the key role of MOFs-based SACs in these batteries by explaining their reaction mechanisms and challenges. Finally, current applications, prospects, and opportunities for MOFs-based SACs in energy storage systems are discussed. Keywords Metal-organic frameworks Single-atom catalysts Rechargeable batteries Electrocatalysts Coordination configuration 1 Introduction With the development of society, the desire to obtain more efficient and environmentally friendly energy storage devices is growing. The next-generation energy storage devices, including fuel cells [1,2], Zn-air batteries [3–5], Li-O2 batteries [6,7], and alkali metal (Li, Na)-chalcogen (S, Se) batteries [8–13], are currently attracting a great deal of interest due to their high energy density and low cost. However, the inherent drawbacks of these batteries inhibited their application in the real industry [14,15]. For example, the performance of fuel cells and metal-air/O2 batteries is affected by the slow oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) process [16,17]; for alkali metal-chalcogen batteries, the performance is seriously affected by the “shuttle effect” due to the dissolution of polysulfides (M2S n , 4 ≤ n ≤ 8, M = Li, Na) and polyselenides (MPSes) intermediates [18]. In response to these problems, one promising solution is introducing a catalyst to the battery system [19]. The well-known working principle of catalyst is to lower the transfer energy barriers of the intermediates to increase the reaction kinetics. So far, different catalysts such as metal sulfides, metal oxides, and Mxene have been developed and well applied in energy storage systems [17,20–22]. Among all types of catalyst, single-atom catalysts (SACs), which consists of catalytical metals at an atomic level, have been the research frontier in recent years [23,24]. SACs exhibit following advantages: (i) the unsaturated coordination environment of metal components can improve the catalytic behaviors [25–28]; (ii) the maximum atom utilization realizes the high theoretical catalytic efficiency (100%) and good selectivity for catalytic reactions [29,30]; (iii) the specific structure characterization is beneficial to design catalysts from the structural level [31]. However, despite these advantages, the problem of atomic agglomeration with increased surface energy and low single-atom loading (typically <1 wt%) severely hampers the application of SACs [32]. At present, researchers have successfully developed various strategies to synthesize SACs, such as atomic-layer deposition, ball-milling, wet-chemistry, and pyrolysis technique of metal-containing organic precursors. Among them, the strategy of using metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as precursors or templates to synthesize SACs shows the increasing interest from researchers [33–35]. MOFs are a class of crystalline porous materials consisting of metal ions/clusters and organic metal-linkers spontaneously assembled by strong coordination bonds [36,37]. MOFs possess a variety of compositional properties, such as ease of functionalization, structural modulation and detection, high surface area, and well-defined molecular adsorption sites [38]. These properties make MOFs show great promise for many applications such as gas separation/storage, sensing, optoelectronics, energy storage, and catalysis [39–41]. So far, some reviews on MOF-based SACs have been reported. However, to the best of our knowledge, there is still a lack of a systematic summary of MOF-based SACs for battery applications, including fuel cells, Zn-air batteries, Li-O2 batteries, and alkali metal (Li, Na)-chalcogen (S, Se) batteries (Fig. 1 ). Based on the merits of MOF structures, the SACs fabricated from MOFs exhibit unique catalytic behaviors with significant advantages. Therefore, this review focused on the state-of-the-art progress of MOF-based SACs for energy storage systems. Specifically, we first classify the reported synthetic strategies from MOFs to SACs with a comparison of the advantages of each strategy, followed by the advanced characterizations for SACs. Then, we describe the basic operating principles of new-generation energy storage devices to explain the importance of introducing SACs and illustrate the benefits of using MOF-based SACs. Finally, the challenges and future priorities of this research topic are proposed. 2 The fabrication of MOFs-based SACs The definition of SACs can be traced back to single-site heterogeneous catalysts (SSHCs), which were first reported by Thomas in 2005. The definition of SSHCs is ‘‘the single site may consist of one or more atoms, but each site is structurally well characterized, spatially isolated, and has the same energy of interaction between it and a reactant as every other single site, just as the single sites inhomogeneous molecular catalysts are’’ [42,43]. SSHCs with highly dispersed and consistent active sites exhibit activity and selectivity for reactions. Similar to SSHCs, SACs are a class of highly dispersed catalysts, which is “a supported metal catalyst exclusively containing isolated monometallic active sites on a surface”, as defined by Zhang’s group [44]. In recent years, the unsaturated coordination condition and maximum catalytic efficiency have made SACs promising catalysts. However, because of the high surface energy of substances dispersed at the atomic level, it is challenging to maintain the metal in a single-atom state during the synthesis process [45]. Therefore, fabricating the stable SACs with high loading is a crucial issue for its application. Among all kinds of materials, MOF has been regarded as one of the promising precursors for SAC fabrication. Since Prof. Yaghi reported the first structure in 1995 [46], MOFs have shown great promise in gas storage/separation [47–50], catalysis [51–53], sensing [54–56], and energy storage [57–60] applications. MOF-based SACs exhibit the following advantages. Firstly, the unique structure of the MOF body, such as high surface area, uniform and well-defined pore size, and highly tunable structure, can all be inherited into the MOF-based SACs. Secondly, the metal nodes in MOFs are highly dispersed at the atomic level and there are abundant N and O nodes bonded to build stable SACs. And it has been demonstrated that this can effectively avoid the aggregation of single atoms after heat treatment [61,62]. Thirdly, the distances of adjacent metal atoms can be artificially adjusted by modifying the size of ligands and adding volatile metal centers to promote the formation of isolated metal atoms [63]. In addition, various metal centers in MOFs can also enhance the metal loading and optimize the electronic structure of the catalyst [64]. Therefore, the fabrication of MOF-based SACs is meaningful work. 3 MOFs strategies to fabricate SACs The established strategies for the synthesis of SACs based on MOFs can be classified into two major categories (Fig. 2 ). The first one is the MOF-supported strategy, in which MOFs act directly as a support carrier for SACs without any treatment to the MOFs pristine structure, and the organic metal-linkers in the framework are almost inherited. The second category is the MOF-derived strategy, which is based on the pyrolysis of MOFs to derive materials with higher electronic conductivity and stability of SACs than the first strategy, thus extending the application of SACs. 3.1 MOF-supported SACs The strategies to synthesize MOF-supported SACs include that: (i) the organic metal-linkers provide abundant N and O coordination sites to stable metal atoms; (ii) the unsaturated junctions in MOFs can provide anchoring centers for metal atoms; (iii) the guest spaces of MOFs can be used to store metal-containing precursors (such as Anderson polyoxometalate (POMs) [65], metal complexes, metal-doped g-C3N4 [66], N-doped carbon [45], metal oxides [67], and single-atom alloys [68]). In this part, the reported studies of using organic linkers, metal nodes, and guest spaces to stabilize SACs are elucidated. 3.1.1 Metal single atoms immobilized by metal-linkers of MOFs Ligands rich in lone electron pairs, which could coordinate with metals, are widely present in the organic linkers of MOFs. Metal atoms with electron deficiencies in the d orbitals are readily attracted to these ligands to form stable metal monoatomic. The pioneering work based on this strategy is reported by Szilágyi’s group [69]. They used the NH2-MIL-101 (Cr-MOF) with 2-nitro-1,4-benzenedicarboxylic ligand to anchor Pd atoms with the loading of 0.85 wt% (Fig. 3 a). The successful preparation of Pt-SACs was convinced by the Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) with the polarization of the NH bond in the MOF structure after the addition of palladium salt (Fig. 3b). And the formation of Pd in Pd(H2) form was confirmed by the density functional theory (DFT) calculations (Fig. 3c), suggesting the feasibility of this method. In order to increase the Pt loading, Zuo et al. [70] prepared a Pt-SAC by a polyvinylpyrrolidone stable coordination method. The MOF support was assembled by Pt-TCPP (TCPP = tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin) and Cu2(COO)4 clusters, and the Pt-SAC was generated directly during the self-assembly of the MOF (Fig. 3d). Notably, the stabilizing effect of polyvinylpyrrolidone greatly reduces the buildup of MOFs during self-assembly so that the SAC exhibits good processability and up to 12 wt% Pt-SAC was loaded in the composite (Fig. 3e). Furthermore, Pardo’s group [71] developed a strategy for the in situ generation of Pd-SAC in an S-containing Cu&Sr-MOFs. The abundant S sites in the metal-linkers supported the Pd2+ coordination, and then the Pd-SAC was synthesized by the in situ reduction of Pd2+ with sodium borohydride and the Pd loading can reach 2 wt%. More recently, Chen et al. [72] synthesized a Cu-SAC (Cu content of 0.43 wt%) from the Uio-67/N-heterocyclic carbene composite. The atomic Cu atoms are stabilized by carbon in the carbene with Cu–C bonds (Fig. 3f–i). Such electron-rich carbene increased the surface charge density and enhanced the gas-phase catalytic activity of Cu-SAC. In addition, Jiang’s group synthesized MOF-supported Ni-SACs with a tunable coordination microenvironment by a microwave-assisted method. The Zr6-oxo cluster in Zr-MOF (i.e., UiO-66-NH2) with adjacent –O/–OH x groups provides the lone pair electrons to support the coordination of metal monoatomic. The UiO-66-NH2 combined with Ni ions undergoes further sulfation to form Ni-SACs with multiple coordination environments (Ni loading of 1.37 wt%). This study confirms the advantages of MOF as a carrier for the fabrication of highly loaded SACs with tunable coordination microenvironments [73]. At present, a variety of metal linkers have been applied to fabricate MOF-supported SACs with good dispersion and high single-atom loadings. This breakthrough has provided valuable experience in the development of MOF-supported SACs. 3.1.2 Metal single atoms immobilized by metal nodes of MOFs In the MOFs structure, some metal nodes are unsaturated to some extent, which can provide additional coordination sites to construct SACs directly [74,75]. As a representative example, Abdel-Mageed et al. [76] performed a pioneering study on this strategy. They first synthesized a MOF (UiO-66 with Zr cluster) carrier with unliganded –OH or –OH2 ligands at the metal nodes and then immobilized Cu atoms by the unsaturated metal node to form a Cu-SAC (Cu/UiO-66) by liquid phase and high-temperature curing processes (Fig. 4 a–c). Owing to the good thermal stability of UiO-66, the basic structure of the MOF is maintained after curing the Cu atoms at high temperatures. Similarly, Sun et al. [77] studied the coordination of precious metal atoms to defects in MOFs metal nodes. They have replaced a portion of the Ni metal nodes in the MOF with Ru using a liquid phase replacement method (Fig. 4d and e). This method replaced 13% of Ni in the original MOF (Ni-BDC (BDC = 1,4-dicarboxybenzene)) by Ru and synthesized Ru-SAC (denoted as NiRu0.13-BDC). Besides, due to the excellent catalytic activity, MOF-supported SACs have also received great attention in the biomedical field and several relevant studies have been reported. For example, Wang et al. [78] successfully embedded Ru atoms in the metal node defects of the MOF body to obtain a monoatomic enzyme (OxgeMCC-r SAE) with a uniform dispersion of Ru based on a self-assembly-one-step liquid-phase substitution method (Fig. 4f–h). This catalyst has a high Ru-SAC loading of 2.23 wt% and a homogeneous morphology. The HAADF image and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectrum of Ru 3d orbital also confirm that Ru components were doped in MOF as monomers (Fig. 4i and j). The design of well-defined catalytic active sites by this method expands the application of MOF-supported high-performance catalysts. 3.1.3 Metal single atoms immobilized in guest space of MOFs One of the features of MOFs is the well-defined and adjustable porous structures, which can effectively separate metal monoatomic, metal nanoparticles, and metal clusters with pore size differences. Compared with the two previously mentioned strategies, synthesizing SAC by confining metal monatomic-containing species as guests in the MOF pores does not impose restrictions on forming chemical bonds between MOF structure and SACs. This approach eliminates the procedures such as heating, solvent evacuation, or chemical exposure to stabilize the MOFs framework integrity. Notably, such SACs embedded MOF retains almost the complete structure of both SACs and MOF, thus, having a high potential to realize synergistic catalysis [79]. It should be noted that for a long time, this synthesis method was only theoretically feasible. Until recently, Hupp’s group provided a strong validation of the feasibility of this synthetic approach [80]. They used a Mo-based POM (ammonium molybdate) as a metal carrier to anchor Rh atoms to form an Rh-containing nanoscale composite (abbreviated as RhMo6O24). Rh-SAC was then synthesized by confining RhMo6O24 in the pores of a Zr(IV)-MOF (denoted as NU1K) through a liquid-phase substitution method (Fig. 5 a–i). The mechanism of this method is “size-matching”, which means the MOF’s pore size should match the size of single atom precursors. In this case, the c-pore size of NU1K is 10 Å and the dimension of POM is 8.55 Å×8.55 Å×3.15 Å, and thus the POM can spontaneously be adsorbed in the pores of NU1K. This method effectively isolates Rh atoms and facilitates the synthesis of stable, homogeneous SACs by the repeated cage structural confinement of the three-dimensional MOF. Their work confirms that MOFs can be tuned with different pore sizes to match the metal-containing monatomic species for SACs fabrication. The presence of metal-containing species as guests in MOFs integrates almost all the advantages of the guests and the MOFs, which has profound implications for enhancing catalytic synergy. 3.2 MOF-derived SACs Different from immobilizing SACs into MOFs directly, another method to fabricate SACs is to derive them from MOFs by heat treatment. This section summarizes the synthetic strategy for MOF-derived SACs based on different reaction mechanisms. As depicted in Fig. 6 (blue section), the widely used methods can be classified into four categories: the direct pyrolysis method [81–83], the pyrolysis&pickling method [84–86], the gasification synthesis method [87,88], and the nanocasting&pyrolysis method [89]. 3.2.1 Direct pyrolysis method The principle of synthesizing SACs by direct pyrolysis method is to carbonize metal-containing MOF precursors at high temperatures under an inert atmosphere [90]. Among all fabrication methods for SACs, this is the most facile one. However, generally, the direct pyrolysis of MOFs may generate metal nanoparticles instead of single atoms; therefore, this method is only applicable to some MOFs. For instance, Shi et al. fabricated a Zn-SAC by carbonizing the hollow structured zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) precursor at 800 °C under Ar flow. Notably, the Zn loading content in such SAC can reach up to 15.7 wt% [91]. Besides using MOFs alone, applying additives can help the dispersion of single metals. For example, Zhang et al. [92] synthesized a Bi-SAC by direct pyrolysis of dicyandiamide-based Bi-MOF at 1000 °C (Fig. 7 a). The use of dicyandiamide can effectively redisperse the generated Bi nanoparticles into single atoms by generating NH3 during high-temperature decomposition. Consequently, the obtained Bi atoms show a well dispersion with a loading of 0.2 wt% (Fig. 7b–d). In addition to the metal source, MOF derivatives were also used as the coordination support to fabricate different SACs. For instance, to prepare Ni-SAC-based composite, Yang et al. first derived N-doped carbon support (denoted as NC) from ZIF-8 by simple pyrolysis and then loaded Ni nanoparticles on the surface of NC support (denoted as Ni NPs@NC) by centrifugation process, followed by thermal treatment to convert Ni NPs@NC to Ni SACs (Fig. 8 a–d) [93]. The developed Ni-SAC is enriched with Ni single atoms only on the surface of the support, providing superior activity, selectivity, and stability compared to that dispersed throughout the carrier. Interestingly, besides coordinating on a carbon support, Zhao et al. reported the fabrication of Pd-SAC by stabilizing Pd on oxygen (O*) vacancies of ZrO2 [83]. They first synthesized a MOF precursor of PdCl2@UiO-66-NH2 using ZrCl4, NH2-H2BDC (2-aminoterephthalic acid), and PdCl2 (Fig. 8f). Then, the precursors were subjected to high-temperature decomposition in an Ar atmosphere to form Pd1@NC/ZrO2 (Fig. 8g), which were further pyrolyzed in the air condition to form a rigid ZrO2 porous nanoweb (Pd1@ZrO2) eventually. This nanoweb promotes the migration of dispersed Pd1 clusters and the formation of Pd1 single atoms with a loading of 0.44 wt% (Fig. 8h). Besides single metal-based MOFs, bimetallic-based MOFs, typically one metal is Zn, are another commonly used precursor to fabricate SACs since Zn with the boiling point of only 907 °C is easy to evaporate. This property can be utilized to obtain SACs of metals with boiling points higher than 907 °C since the Zn component can be removed by direct high-temperature treatment and only separated metals are left. Such an approach of using bimetallic-based MOFs solves the limitation of using MOFs alone, which can only fabricate the same metal atom from the MOF structure. Besides, the metal content can be adjusted by adding different content ratios of Zn and other metal salts during the formation of bimetal-MOFs. The first application of direct pyrolysis of bimetallic-based MOFs for SACs fabrication was reported by Lin’s group [94]. As depicted in Fig. 8(i), they prepared an electrocatalyst containing FeNC active sites by pyrolysis of the Fe-doped ZIF-8. By utilizing the boiling point difference between metallic Zn (907 °C) and Fe (2750 °C), after 1000 °C treatment, the Zn component was evaporated and only the highly dispersed Fe atoms were left with the loading of 0.15 wt%. These experimental results served as guidance for further optimization and improvement of this synthesis strategy. Because the abundant outer d orbital electrons in transition metals are prone to coordinate with defect sites in MOF-derived carbon matrix, different transition metal SACs such as Co [95], Ag [96], Pt [97], and Ir [98] have been derived from bimetallic-based MOF precursors. In conclusion, the successful practice of the direct pyrolysis method provides advanced ideas for exploring subsequent synthesis strategies. 3.2.2 Pyrolysis&pickling method The pyrolysis&pickling method is currently the most common one for SAC synthesis. After pyrolysis, the originally uniformly attached metals are easy to agglomerate on the surface of the support and only a small amount of SACs is obtained since the coordination sites are reduced after carbonization [99]. By the pickling method, excess metal clusters or free-standing metals can be removed effectively, leaving SACs anchored on MOF-derived carbon matrix. For example, Han et al. [100] prepared a Co SAC by evaporating the Zn atoms in a Zn/Co bimetal-MOF under high temperature and followed by removing the Co clusters formed under carbonization by pickling, resulting in the uniform distribution of Co SACs with the loading of 1.70 wt% (Fig. 9 a). Fe-SACs have been extensively studied due to their higher catalytic effect among non-precious metals. However, the commonly used method for loading Fe atoms in MOF derivatives (such as the direct pyrolysis method described previously) shows a low metal content (generally below 1 wt%) [62,101,102], which will affect the catalytic efficiency [103]. One method to break this confinement is to optimize the coordination support to stabilize more Fe single atoms. Jiang’s group [104] chose to make a breakthrough by modifying the MOF structure. Instead of choosing the commonly used ZIF-8, they synthesized a hexagonal columnar Fe-MOF with TCPP (tetrakis(4-carboxyphenyl) porphyrin) as the ligand and followed by acid treatment to prepare Fe SAC. Owing to the unique shape of this Fe-MOF, the spatial distance of Fe atoms in the structure was apparently extended, which can effectively suppress Fe aggregation during pyrolysis. Based on this method, the content of Fe atoms reached a high loading of 1.76 wt% (Fig. 9b). Given the great diversity and customizability of MOFs, this work provides a new strategy for the rational synthesis of efficient SACs through multi-scale control. Besides using MOFs alone, introducing surfactant to the MOF system can also assist the metal confinement. This method was first reported by He et al. [105]. They derived a highly dispersed Co catalyst with a core–shell structure from the Pluronic® F-127-coated MOF precursor (Fig. 9c). This carbon shell can effectively retain the micropores and N active sites in the carbon matrix after pyrolysis, thus preventing the aggregation of Co atoms. Furthermore, the cohesive interaction between the selected Pluronic® F-127 and the Co-doped ZIF-8 nanocrystals creates a confinement effect on the whole system, which can inhibit the agglomeration of Co atoms during the pyrolysis process and mitigate the collapse of the microporous structure of ZIF-8. Compared to Co-SAC synthesized without surfactant assistance, the Co loading in Co-SAC increased from 0.23 wt% to 0.77 wt% after Pluronic® F-127-assisted treatment. This sacrificial framework approach has also been used to prepare SACs with different metals such as Mn [106], Cr [107], W [108], and Ru [109,110]. 3.2.3 Gasification synthesis method Aiming to obtain SACs with higher loadings more economically and efficiently, researchers have paid much attention to synthesizing SACs from the simultaneous pyrolysis process of MOFs, metal, or metal compounds [111]. As suggested by Li et al., the coordination bonds formed by metal atoms and N atoms (M−N) possess more robust thermal stability than metallic bonds [112]. With this line, researchers tried to synthesize the desired SACs by exciting or heating the corresponding metal or metal compounds to form a mobile vapor, which was then stabilized by the MOF-derived porous carbon matrix. A relatively early study was reported by Qu et al. [95] who synthesized Cu SAC by placing Cu foam and ZIF-8 at the front and back of the tube furnace following argon flow direction, respectively (Fig. 10 a). ZIF-8 forms a porous carbon matrix with many empty coordination sites during graphitization in an argon atmosphere. After this, ammonia gas is introduced to drag out Cu atoms from the Cu foam surface at high temperatures and form volatile Cu-ammonia complexes owing to the strong Lewis acid-base interactions. The complexes were then trapped by defects in the porous carbon skeleton, generating a highly dispersed Cu-SA/NC catalyst with Cu loading of 0.54 wt%. Notably, for most metals, direct gasification of pure metals would require high reaction temperature and result in unnecessary energy waste. Therefore, some studies have used metal compounds with lower decomposition temperature as metal sources. For instance, Deng et al. [113] used ferrocene instead of iron metal as Fe source to synthesize SACs since the boiling point of ferrocene (249 °C) is much lower than Fe (2750 °C). During the heating process, ferrocene molecules were evaporated and captured by ZIF-8, and followed by further heating to 950 °C, the ferrocene was converted to Fe-atoms and anchored by the ZIF-8 derived nitrogen-doped porous carbon matrix to synthesize Fe-SAC composite with Fe-N x active sites (Fe loading of 1 wt%) (Fig. 10b). 3.2.4 Nanocasting&pyrolysis method Despite the advantages of MOF precursors mentioned above, the structural stability of MOFs should not be ignored since the structures of MOFs tend to decompose under high temperatures [114]. To strengthen the framework, researchers have recently developed a class of nanocasting frame stabilization strategies. This strategy provides thermally stable secondary scaffolds for MOF-based catalytic unit sites, which can effectively stabilize the MOFs structure, limit metal aggregation during pyrolysis, and increase the metal loading [89]. Inspired by the widely used nanocasting technique for mesoporous materials, Jiao et al. [115] proposed a nanocasting study by introducing SiO2 into the mesoporous system of Fe-based porphyrinic MOF. This system contains a Fe(III) atom in each porphyrin linkage site (Fig. 11 a). Due to the presence of one-dimensional mesoporous channels, SiO2 columns are cast in the voids of hexagonal columnar MOFs as supports, which can stabilize the metal nanoparticles by reducing the surface energy of the metal atoms, thereby increasing the metal atom loading, making full use of the pores in the MOFs, and forming a thermally stable FeN4/SiO2 composite. After pyrolysis and removal of the SiO2 support by acid etching, monoatomic Fe catalysts with a high loading of 3.46 wt% were obtained (Fig. 11b and c). In addition, inspired by the direct involvement of Zn metalloenzymes in biocatalysts studies, Xu et al. [116] employed this SiO2 nanocasting strategy combined with ZIF-8 to fabricate Zn-SACs. Particularly, they synthesized the precursors under an alkaline environment and then isolated the Zn-SAC (Zn loading of 3.12 wt%) after high-temperature hydrolysis, followed by alkaline washing to remove the supporting SiO2. Owing to the abundant and highly dispersed Fe-N4 active sites in the synthesized nanozymes, the nanozyme shows comparable activity to natural enzymes. Similarly, Chen et al. [62] developed a MOF@polymer strategy to fabricate an Fe-SA-based catalyst, where the Fe single atoms were anchored on N, P, and S co-doped films of hollow carbon polyhedral (Fe-SAs/NPS-HC). The ZIF-8 was used as a sacrificial template and its dodecahedral framework structure was strengthened by the coated polymer (monomers of poly(cyclo-triphospazene-co-4,4′-sulfonyldiphenol)) (Fig. 11d). After high-temperature treatment, Fe-SACs (Fe loading of 1.54 wt%) anchored on functionalized hollow structures were constructed, which successfully inherited the dodecahedral conformation after pyrolysis (Fig. 11e and f). To sum up, the progress mentioned above confirms that MOFs are ideal precursors to fabricate SACs. Different kinds of SACs, such as Co, Ni, Cu, Fe, Pt, Ru, have been coordinated by doping ligands and the spatial confinement of MOFs. Nevertheless, currently, the highest SA loading achieved by MOF-based precursors is around 10 wt%, which is insufficient for real applications, and fabricating SACs with high loading and abundant active sites is still a great challenge. It is worth noting that when designing a new MOF precursor, the ligand selection is a double-edged sword. On the one hand, long ligands with more branched chains can effectively separate metal nodes and alleviate metal aggregation during the pyrolysis process. On the other hand, long and large ligands will reduce the metal content in the MOF, which is unfavorable for SAC preparation. Moreover, ligands with high content of heteroatom doping show great advances in SAC stability. Therefore, MOF crystals with optimized structures are still in high demand. 4 The characterization of MOFs-based SACs After the synthesis of MOF-based SACs, proper characterization techniques are required to identify the structure and distribution of SACs. In this part, we will elucidate the principles of the characterization techniques for SACs, followed by corresponding applications. Generally, the main characterization techniques include electron microscope imaging and spectroscopic analysis techniques. Aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (AC HAADF-STEM) is the only characterization method in electron microscopy imaging techniques that can effectively identify SACs directly by the brightness difference between metals and non-metals [117]. The spectroscopic analysis techniques contain electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS), synchrotron radiation-based X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) (includes the X-ray absorption near-edge spectroscopy (XANES) spectroscopy and extended X-ray fine structure spectroscopy (EXAFS)), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and infrared (IR) spectroscopy (Fig. 12 ). Generally, these characterization techniques can confirm the presence of single atoms in a material independently and effectively. Typically, a combination of characterization methods is required to obtain complete information about the morphology, structure, catalytic centers, and electronic properties of SACs. In addition, DFT calculations also work as a promising tool to provide unique insights into the reaction mechanisms of SACs and the distribution of active centers. 4.1 Electron microscope imaging and EELS spectrum The most intuitive way to observe SAC is to image the dispersion of single atoms in the material directly. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) is one of the most widely used techniques in this study [118]. The TEM has both bright-field and weak-beam dark-field modes, and AC-TEM in bright-field (high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM)) and dark-field (HAADF-STEM) modes are widely used to observe the atomic structure information such as size and dispersion of SACs [119–121]. According to the Rutherford scattering principle [122], the intensity of images collected from HAADF-STEM is proportional to the square of the atomic number of the selected element (Z 2). Thus HAADF-STEM can identify single atomic sites from bright spots at the atomic level where atoms of different masses show clear contrast. It is worth noting that sample defects, impurities, or low sample flatness may also show bright spots in HAADF-STEM images. Consequently, the sample should be kept clean and flat before testing and unwanted interference should be eliminated as much as possible. HAADF-STEM images at different focal depths can combine with the EELS or energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy to analyze the structure, chemical composition, valence, and spatial distribution of SACs [123]. For example, Wu et al. fabricated a Fe-SAC using the stepwise pyrolysis method and then observed the atomic coordination information between Fe and N using HAADF-STEM images with EELS curves (Fig. 13 a–c) [124]. Notably, although the techniques mentioned above can provide direct information about SACs, the tests are performed in a high-energy electron beam environment, which may cause spatial jumps and dynamic migration of atomic sites, and thus may lead to inaccurate atomic characterization [125]. To solve this problem, some researchers use low-temperature scanning tunneling microscopy (LT-STM) combined with EELS analysis to obtain more accurate characterization images. As displayed in Fig. 13(d–f), by combining HRTEM and LT-STM tests, Deng et al. [126] observed for the first time a well-defined Fe-N4 atomic structure in the graphene carrier. 4.2 Spectroscopic techniques 4.2.1 XAFS techniques The spectral data obtained by synchrotron radiation-based XAFS are sensitive to the changes in the electronic structure, local atomic configuration, and coordination forms of the selected elements [127]. Compared to XRD and XPS, XAFS is an informative and powerful characterization technique that provides richer information about the local electronic structure, electronic environment, and atomic coordination of SACs [128]. XAFS spectrum consists of two parts, one is the absorption band in the low energy region within −20 eV to 50 eV near the absorption edge (XANES) and the other one is the fine structure located between 50 eV and 1000 eV (or even higher energy) from the absorption edge (EXAFS) [129]. Among them, the XANES spectrum can determine the symmetry information of the planes and analyze the oxidation state, geometric structure, and electronic configuration of the local central atom by the energy variation of the X-ray absorption edge. Moreover, XANES is proportional to the projection density of unoccupied electron states, this can be used to quantitatively determine the electronic structure and electronic deficiency of metal atoms [130,131]. The EXAFS spectral data are analyzed by Fourier transform (FT) and least squares curve fitting to obtain structure information such as radial distribution, interatomic distances, coordination numbers, and bond lengths. The wavelet transform (WT) spectrum can additionally reveal the wave number dependence of the scattering [132,133]. Notably, the presence of metal bonds in the sample can be analyzed from the EXAFS spectra, which provides important evidence of whether all metal components are dispersed at the monoatomic level. Therefore, XAFS, which provides essential structure information on monoatomic metals, has been widely used to identify SACs. For example, as depicted in Fig. 14 (a), Wei et al. prepared a Pt-SAC decorated Mn tetroxide nanosheet (PtSA-Mn3O4) and characterized the coordination of Pt-SAC by XANES [134]. The energy absorption threshold of the Pt L3-edge in PtSA-Mn3O4 was located between Pt foil and PtO2, indicating that the monatomic Pt is positively charged and electrons are transferred from Pt to O atom in Mn3O4. Among them, the peak intensity of PtSA-Mn3O4 can also be effectively analyzed for the 5d orbital electronic state in Pt. As depicted in Fig. 14(b), the EXAFS spectrum of PtSA–Mn3O4 showed a dominant peak at 2.05 Å and no Pt–Pt contribution peak, confirming the presence of only Pt single atoms. To obtain more accurate results, an ultra-high-resolution WT analysis equipped with R and k-space was performed (Fig. 14c). The spectra show a clear difference between the spectral intensity maxima of PtSA-Mn3O4, Pt foil, and PtO2, which confirms the monoatomic dispersion of Pt. The high spectra similarity of the PtSA-Mn3O4 and PtO2 in the region of radial distance 1–2.5 Å implies that they contain similar Pt–O bonds. The FT-EXAFS spectra of Pt K-edge showed a broad peak at 2 Å, which could be assigned to the scattering path of the Pt–O bond located in the PtSA-Mn3O4 sample (Fig. 14d). Based on the above analysis, the local structure of PtSA-Mn3O4 shows the Pt single atoms anchored in the octahedra of the Mn3O4 nanosheet matrix, which is connected by two O atoms to form a 6-ligand structure. The successful application of in situ/operando XAFS has provided an effective way to dynamically monitor the geometry and electronic environment of catalytic sites at the atomic scale during reactions. Recently, Wan et al. [135] designed a Co-SAC for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER). They performed in situ XAS tests on the Co K-edge of the catalyst by a homemade electrochemical cell. A comprehensive analysis of the in situ XANES spectrograms at different potentials and the normalized Co K-edge XANES spectrograms revealed an increasing trend of the oxidation state of Co atoms in the catalyst during the HER process (Fig. 14e and f). Subsequently, the in situ EXAFS analysis of the K-edge of the Co single atom in the catalyst was performed to obtain k 3-weighted FT-EXAFS spectra, and the curves yielded dominant peak positions attributable to Co–N and Co–P coordination and a shoulder peak position revealed the coordination structure of Co (Fig. 14g). In conclusion, the application of in situ XAS technique successfully revealed the electronic and atomic structures of isolated Co-P1N3 monomer in Co-SA/P and explained the relationship between bond length extension and high HER activity. Compared to other characterization methods, operando XAFS measurements can further clarify the coordination environment of the catalytic active center and the possible changes in electronic properties during the catalytic reaction. For example, Yaghi’s group [76] prepared a Cu-SAC immobilized on –OH/–OH2 oxygen atoms. To study the electronic properties of Cu atoms and possible changes of the local coordination environment during the catalytic reaction, they performed time-resolved operando XAFS measurements on the Cu K-edge. The obtained XANES and EXAFS data clarified the oxidation state of Cu SAC during the catalytic reaction and confirmed the high stability of the coordination environment around the Cu atoms. 4.2.2 IR spectroscopy The IR technique can effectively identify and distinguish the presence of SACs by monitoring the vibration frequency changes of the probe molecule after forming the chemical bond when it is adsorbed on the metal surface [136]. The widely used probe molecules are CO [137], NH3 [138], trimethyl-phosphine oxide (TMPO) [139], and deuterated acetonitrile [140]. CO is often used as a probe molecule because of its merits of small size, easy diffusion, and strong interactions with metal atoms; and the central structure of the metal can be identified by the changes in the COad peak position in the IR spectrum [136,141,142]. For example, DeRita et al. [136] synthesized a stable Ptiso catalyst, in which Pt was confirmed to be monotonically dispersed by an integrated strategy using probe molecular IR spectroscopy and STEM analysis. For catalysts with varying Pt contents, they tested the CO-probe molecular IR spectra and STEM images under saturated CO coverage (Fig. 15 a–c). The intensity of the peak near 2100 cm−1 is larger than that of other broad peaks, indicating the existence of Pt-SAC since the metal single atoms exhibit stronger interactions with the probe molecules compared to the large metal clusters, which is also consistent with the observation of small bright spots in STEM images. In order to characterize the surface structure and composition of SACs, some studies chose further to analyze the samples by FT-IR analysis of CO adsorption. Zhang et al. [143] analyzed the alloyed Pd-SACs with Au as a carrier by diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFT). Two peaks can be distinguished in Fig. 15(d), which correspond to the CO absorption bands at the bridge or hollow sites (∼1900 cm−1) and CO absorption bands on the top sites of Pd (∼2000 cm−1). With the increase of Au/Pd ratio, the intensity of CO at bridging sites shows a decreasing trend; and when the ratio of Au/Pd is higher or equal to 4, the material contains a large amount of Pd single atoms. In the tests of different Au/Pd ratios in various CO pressures, the frequency of CO adsorbed at the bridging sites with lower Au/Pd ratios was blue-shifted with the increase of CO pressure due to the coupling effect between dipoles (Fig. 15e and f). Moreover, as the Au/Pd ratio increases, the bridged CO shifts irregularly in IR frequency due to electronic modification, size change, etc. So, the evidence provided by the DRIFT technique can effectively confirm the form of metal atoms in the material. 4.2.3 In situ XPS XPS is an analytical method based on the Einstein photoelectric effect to analyze the valence and elemental composition of a material. In-situ XPS based on synchrotron light sources allows for real-time tracking of valence and elemental composition changes during the reaction. For instance, Hu et al. [144] used in situ XPS (Mg K α) to dynamically monitor the Pd/CeO2 (i.e., Pd n /CeO2(111) and Pd1/CeO2(100)) catalysts to understand the crystallographic effects and the valence changes of Pd, O, and Ce during preparation. The in situ XPS spectra data of O 1s for the two catalysts show completely different results, where the ratio of O2− in Pd1/CeO2(100) exhibits a decreasing trend with increasing temperature (Fig. 16 a). Based on the in situ XPS curves of Pd 3d, the changes in the coordination form of Pd and the valence state of Pd throughout the process at different temperatures can be analyzed. Furthermore, by monitoring the Ce 3d signal in both catalyst materials, it was found that the proportion of Ce3+ also differed significantly with temperature. The results of this work reveal that the in situ XPS testing technique shows significant advantages for studying the chemical composition, state, and thermal stability of SACs. 4.3 DFT calculations The DFT is a powerful tool for studying catalyst properties for SACs at the atomic level. By performing the DFT calculations for the catalyst, the stable configuration and catalytic mechanism can be well examined [145–147]. The DFT calculations provide unique advantages in obtaining detailed data on the Gibbs free energy (ΔG), material defects, electronic structure, and charge distribution of the catalyst. The integration of DFT calculations into the experimental facts has provided a useful supplement, which is beneficial for the comprehensive understanding of SACs’ behaviors. Taking Fe-SAC as an example, Wang et al. [148] fabricated a Fe-SA-CN catalyst containing the Fe-N4 active site by precisely controlling the Fe content in ZIF-8. As shown in Fig. 16(b and c), they constructed two models containing Fe-N4 and Fe-free ligand sites for DFT calculations to study the decomposition process of Li2S in Li-S batteries, respectively. The different reaction energy barriers (1.85 vs. 2.54 eV) of Fe-N4 and Fe-free ligand site vacancies indicate that Li2S decomposes more easily in the catalyst-containing material (Fig. 16d and e). Similarly, Guo’s group performed DFT calculations on the synthesized Co-SAC to further explore and explain the mechanism of Co-SAC for catalyzing ORR/OER in Zn-air batteries [149]. Fig. 16(f) shows a model of the stable adsorption conformation of the OER/ORR intermediates (OOH*, OH*, and O*) at the Co single-atom/cluster site. The lower proton and charge transfer barriers of Co-SAC to adsorbed OH* were confirmed by calculating the ΔG of the catalyst for the 4 e− ORR reaction process in alkaline electrolytes (Fig. 16g). DFT calculations of the free energy pathways of the ORR/OER process showed that the downhill potentials of the two processes were 0.85 and 1.63 V, respectively (Fig. 16h and i), theoretically demonstrating the excellent catalytic activity of the synthesized Co-SAC in Zn-air batteries. The above ex situ and in situ techniques are powerful tools for SACs characterization. Nevertheless, for MOF-based SACs, the structural characterization of MOF supports usually is ignored. The coordination configuration of MOFs crystals can be directly obtained by X-ray single-crystal diffraction, which also provides valuable structural information for SACs. When MOFs are used as a precursor, the framework may collapse and functional groups evaporate under high temperatures. Therefore, some characterization techniques such as solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) and time of flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (TOF-SIMIS) are needed to bridge the structures before and after carbonization, which can be utilized as a reasonable analysis for bonding information of MOF-derived SACs. 5 Advanced fuel cells and rechargeable batteries With the growing environmental problems, it is imperative to develop efficient energy storage and conversion devices for a sustainable future for mankind [150–152]. The new-generation electrochemical energy storage systems, such as fuel cells, Zn-air batteries, Li-O2 batteries, and alkali metal-chalcogen batteries, have attracted much attention from researchers because of their high theoretical energy density, low manufacturing cost, and environmentally friendly features [153]. Furthermore, MOF-based SACs can be applied to these energy storage devices with favorable results due to their excellent catalytic properties [154–156]. In this section, we have briefly explained the reaction principles of these batteries and discussed the challenges that affect their real application. 5.1 The fuel cells The fuel cell, in particular an H2-O2 fuel cell, is an electrochemical device that uses H2 as the fuel and O2 as an oxidizing agent, which can convert chemical energy into electrical energy. The high energy density of H2 (120 MJ kg−1) and the short waiting time (5 min) of fuel cells have attracted extensive research interests [157]. At present, acidic polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) and anion exchange membrane fuel cells (AEMFCs) in fuel cells are given great expectations and extensive research interests by researchers [158,159]. The PEMFCs is a promising renewable energy conversion technology that has been widely used due to the outstanding features of high energy efficiency ratio, high power density, and environmental protection [160,161]. The H2-O2 fuel cells are a typical class of PEMFCs [162]. In the working process, H2 molecules are oxidized on the anode side to produce hydrogen ions, and the cathode undergoes a reaction to reduce O2 molecules. In a sense, this electrode reaction can be seen as the reverse process of electrolysis of water (Fig. 17 a). The specific reactions are shown below [163]. Anode : H 2 ↔ 2H + + 2e - Cathode I : O 2 + 4H + + 4e - ↔ 2H 2 O 4 e - pathway Cathode II : O 2 + 2H + + 2e - ↔ H 2 O 2 2 e - pathway It should be noted that the ORR process has two different oxygen reduction reaction pathways, the 2 e− pathway and the 4 e− pathway, depending on the number of electrons in the reaction [163]. The 4 e− pathway can directly generate H2O, while the 2 e− pathway generates peroxide byproducts (H2O2) and leads to an inefficient ORR process [14,164]. Therefore, compared to the oxidation of H2 in the anode, the ORR process occurring at the cathode is the decisive step in controlling the energy efficiency of the cell. Concerning this, a powerful and efficient catalyst is needed to promote the fuel cell cathode undergoing only 4 e− reduction conversion pathways. Compared with the commercialized PEMFCs, AEMFCs have obvious advantages, such as theoretically more suitable non-precious metal catalysts, stronger adaptability to different fuels, and the use of more environmentally friendly fluoride-free polymer exchange membranes [165–167]. Consequently, the system-level, material-level, and stack-level costs of AEMFCs are lower than those of PEMFCs [165,168]. Structurally, the main difference between AEMFCs and PEMFCs is that the solid membrane in AEMFCs is an alkaline anion exchange membrane (AEM) instead of an acidic polymer electrolyte membrane (PEM) (Fig. 17b). In AEMFCs, OH− is transported across the AEM from the cathode to the anode, which is the opposite direction of H+ conduction in PEMFCs and creates an alkaline cell environment. The following reaction equations can express the electrode reaction in AEMFCs [169,170]. A n o d e : H 2 + 2 O H - ↔ 2 H 2 O + 2 e - C a t h o d e : O 2 + 2 H 2 O + 4 e - ↔ 4 O H - When air is used as the oxygen source, the primary anion on the AEM membrane is OH− produced by the ORR process of the cathode [171]. If H2 is used as the battery fuel, the discharge process of the anode is completed by the oxidation reaction between H2 and OH−. In the study of AEMFCs, the combined effects of electrode composition, structure, and reaction conditions on the transport properties of reactants, products, various ions, and water in the battery ultimately determine the performance of the battery. Among these influencing factors, the most influential one is the imbalance between the water consumption at the cathode and the water generation at the anode. This imbalance worsens performance since the cell cannot fully utilize the excess water in the discharge reaction [172]. Moreover, the ORR and OER processes that occur in electrodes are highly dependent on superior catalysts to lower the reaction energy barrier so that these processes can proceed spontaneously. Currently, only platinum group metal (PGM) catalysts are available to enable fuel cells to exhibit appreciable performance, and the performance of PGM-free catalysts in AMEFCs electrodes is only about 40% of cells using Pt/C and PtRh/C catalysts [173–175]. In addition, compared to PGM catalysts, PGM-free catalysts still show drawbacks in material durability and turnover frequency [176]. Therefore, there is still a long way to go before PGM-free catalysts can be successfully used in AEMFCs. 5.2 The Zn-air batteries Among various rechargeable metal batteries, Zn-air batteries are considered a promising energy storage system since it has the highest volumetric specific energy (3921 Wh L−1), the low cost of raw materials, and the use of mild and non-flammable aqueous electrolytes (Fig. 17c) [177,178]. In brief, the operation mechanism of Zn-air batteries is the oxidation-reduction conversion of Zn, O2, and ZnO during discharge and charge processes, which can be described as follows [179–181]. C a t h o d e : O 2 +2 H 2 O+4 e - ↔ 4O H - Anode: Zn(s) ↔ Zn 2+ +2 e - R e g i o n I : Zn 2+ + 2O H - ↔ Zn ( OH ) 2 Region II: Zn ( OH ) 2 ↔ ZnO+H 2 O Total reaction : Zn(s)+ O 2 ↔ 2ZnO(s) During the discharge process, oxygen is captured by the air cathode and reduced to OH− by contact with the catalytic material. Subsequently, OH− is dissolved by the aqueous electrolytes and migrates through the separator to the surface of the Zn anode and reacts with Zn2+ to form soluble zincate ions (Zn(OH)4 2−) (Region I). When the concentration of zincate ions in the electrolyte reaches saturation, it decomposes to form Zn oxide (Region II). Throughout the reaction, electrons released by the reaction of Zn and hydroxide are transferred to the cathode through an external circuit; oxygen in the air contacts with the cathode and an ORR occurs [182]. During the charging process, an OER occurs at the air cathode, and the total cell reaction can be viewed as a process of synthesis and decomposition of ZnO [183]. For an actual application, the Zn-air batteries still suffer from short operating life and low energy conversion efficiency owing to the inherently slow chemical kinetics of the ORR/OER process and the poor stability of the air cathode in a corrosive electrolyte [16]. Thus, developing effective and durable catalysts for the ORR/OER reaction is particularly important. 5.3 The Li-O2 batteries The enthusiasm for Li-O2 batteries stems from their ultra-high theoretical energy density (3505 Wh kg−1 and 3436 Wh L−1), which exceeds most of the batteries invented [184]. In a Li-O2 battery, a series of oxygen reduction processes occur at the cathode (Fig. 17d), and the reaction process of the cell can be described as follows (* indicates side reaction) [185,186]. Anode: Li(s) ↔ Li + + e - C athode: 2 Li + +2 e - + O 2 ↔ Li 2 O 2 R e g i o n I : O 2 + e - ↔ O 2 - R e g i o n I I : O 2 - + Li + ↔ LiO 2 R e g i o n I I I : 2LiO 2 ↔ Li 2 O 2 + O 2 ∗ R e g i o n I V : Li 2 O 2 +2 Li + +2 e - ↔ 2 Li 2 O During the discharge process, the anode releases Li+ in the electrolyte and electrons reach the cathode by the external circuit, while the reaction process at the cathode is relatively complex. Firstly, the O2 on the surface of the cathode is dissociated and reduced to O2 − by adsorption (Region I) and then reacts with Li+ to form LiO2 (Region II) [187]. In the widely studied aprotic electrolyte system, experiments confirm that the discharge reaction generates two Li oxides (Li2O2 and Li2O as shown in Region III and Region IV, respectively) by further reduction [188–190]. Nevertheless, the chemical reactivity of Li2O with organic solvents is much smaller than Li2O2 and LiO2, which makes reducing Li2O to metallic Li very difficult [186]. Therefore, during discharge, the reaction of Region IV needs to be avoided and a catalyst is needed to enhance the reaction selectivity in Region III. Unfortunately, Li2O2 is an insulating substance that is insoluble in the electrolyte and highly susceptible to the passivation of the battery cathode surface. Therefore, making the battery system produce only Li2O2 during discharge also cannot fundamentally improve the actual performance of the battery [191,192]. To cope with these problems, great efforts have been made to find powerful electrocatalysts, which can accelerate the chemical reaction kinetics of Li2O2 generation and decomposition, thus radically improving the performance of Li-O2 batteries [193]. 5.4 The alkali metal-chalcogen batteries The alkali metal-chalcogen batteries, which mainly include Li-S batteries, Li-Se batteries, Na-S batteries, and Na-Se batteries, also receive wide attention due to their high theoretical capacities, low cost, and environmentally friendly merits [194–198]. As categorized in Fig. 17(e and f), these batteries share a similar conversion reaction mechanisms [199,200]. Taking the Li-S battery as an example, it consists of an S-based cathode, a Li-metal anode, a separator, and an organic electrolyte. The cathode and anode are separated by a separator that promotes the passage of ions but prevents electron transfer. The corresponding redox reaction equation is shown below [12,201]. Anode: Li(s) ↔ Li + + e - C athode: n S+2 Li + + 2 e - ↔ Li 2 S n ( 4 ≤ n ≤ 8 ) R e g i o n I : S 8 +2 Li + +2 e - ↔ Li 2 S 8 R e g i o n I I : Li 2 S 8 +2 Li + +2 e - ↔ 2 Li 2 S 4 Region III: 3 Li 2 S 4 +2 Li + +2 e - ↔ 4 Li 2 S 3 Li 2 S 4 +2 Li + +2 e - ↔ 2 Li 2 S 2 R e g i o n I V : Li 2 S 2 +2 Li + +2 e - ↔ 2 Li 2 S During the discharge process, Li+ diffuses from the anode to the cathode, while electrons move from the anode to the cathode through an external circuit [202]. The S-based cathode is mainly in the form of S8 macromolecules, which cannot be directly reduced to Li2S in just one step reaction. Instead, this conversion requires a long process of multi-electron and multiphase changes [203]. When Li+ from the anode reacts with S, the intermediate long-chain LiPSs (Li2S n , 4 ≤ n ≤ 8) are initially produced, which are soluble in the electrolyte; these long-chain LiPSs will turn into water-insoluble Li2S2 in subsequent reactions and finally transfer into Li2S at the fully discharged state. The generated Li2S8 and Li2S4 are soluble in the electrolyte, but S8, Li2S3, Li2S2, and Li2S are insoluble. Therefore, during the discharge process, the S cathode undergoes a phase change process of “solid → liquid → solid” [204]. The Li2S8 and Li2S4 in the electrolyte can cross the separator and reach the anode to react with Li+ directly, which reduces the concentration of reactants after the Region II process, resulting in a low reversible capacity and poor cycling stability [153,205,206]. In addition, compared with sulfur, the use of a Se-based cathode provides higher electron conductivity (2.0 mS m−1) and almost identical volumetric density (over 3200 mA h cm−3) than an S-based cathode [207–209]. The reaction mechanism of the cell using Se as the cathode is similar to that of S, which also suffers from the formation of soluble intermediates with the “shuttle effect” [210]. Besides Li-S/Se batteries, Na-based batteries have also attracted considerable interest from researchers due to the abundant reserves of Na [211]. For room-temperature (RT) Na-S/Se batteries, the reaction processes are similar to that of Li-S/Se batteries. Given this, how to solve the shuttle effect and accelerate the conversion kinetics of MPSs/MPSes is the key factors in enhancing the electrochemical performance of alkali metal-chalcogen batteries [14,212]. Generally, the next-generation energy storage systems of fuel cells, Zn-air batteries, Li-O2 batteries, and alkali metal-chalcogen batteries fulfill the requirements of modern industry. However, the question of how to effectively achieve a fast and efficient cathode reaction during the charge and discharge process is a key issue in developing these devices. Introducing a suitable catalyst to the reaction process is now a promising strategy to reduce the energy barrier and increase the reaction kinetics [213,214]. It is therefore essential to incorporate ideal and efficient catalysts in the device with abundant and evenly distributed active centers. 6 Application of MOFs-based SACs in fuel cells and rechargeable batteries Since the successful preparation of SACs in 2011, many related studies have appeared [25,215]. The synthetic strategy of SACs prepared by MOF precursors was developed in 2016 and first applied to energy storage devices in 2018 with excellent catalytic properties [216]. Since then, MOFs-based SACs have been widely used in fuel cells and rechargeable batteries (Fig. 18 ). When being applied to fuel cells, Zn-air batteries, and Li-O2 batteries, MOF-based SACs have shown great potential to enhance electrode efficiency and reaction selectivity for both ORR and OER processes [217]. In Li/Na-chalcogen batteries, SACs can effectively catalyze the reduction reaction of MPSs and MPSes during the redox reaction, thus alleviating the shuttle effect. The incorporation of SACs in electrode materials has promoted the development of energy storage devices. Reports on the application of MOF-based SACs in batteries have grown in recent years, and the excellent performance shown by SACs in energy storage devices will certainly make them a frontier for future research. This section will discuss the state-of-the-art applications of MOFs-based SACs materials in fuel cells and rechargeable batteries (Fig. 6, green section). 6.1 Application in fuel cells The application and commercialization prospects of fuel cells are severely hampered by the slow ORR kinetics of the cathode in the cell. Commercial platinum group (particularly Pt)-based catalysts (PGM) are the commonly used electrocatalyst for fuel cells [218,219]. However, the PGM are expensive and scarce on the earth, severely inhibiting their large-scale applications. One strategy to reduce PGM usage and improve catalyst utilization is to design PGM-based catalysts at the atomic level. Moreover, the porous and hierarchical structure inherited from the MOF-derived carbon matrix can ease the resistance of mass transport and improve the fuel cell performance [220,221]. As a result, MOF-derived PGM-SACs have been widely studied in fuel cells. For example, Xiong et al. [222] synthesized an Rh-SA-based catalyst (denoted as SA-Rh/CN) by using Rh(III) acetylacetonate (Rh(acac)3) as Rh source and ZIF-8 as a template. When used for the direct formic acid fuel cells (DFAFCs), the SA-Rh/CN based cathode with monoatomic Rh loading of 0.92 wt% exhibited a 28-fold higher mass activity than the state-of-the-art Pd/C electrode (Pt content of 30 wt%). To study the coordination principle of the active site for precious metal single-atom catalysts (PM-SACs), Liu et al. [223] prepared a series of PM-SACs, including Ir, Rh, Pt, and Pd by doping them into the ZIF-derived N-doped carbon matrix (denoted as Ir-N/C, Rh-N/C, Pt-N/C, Pd -N/C, respectively) (Fig. 19 a). The ORR activities of Ir-N/C and Rh-N/C in acidic half-cell are higher than that of nanoparticle sized catalysts (denoted as Ir/C and Rh/C). Interestingly, compare with Pd/C and Pt/C nanoparticle catalysts, they observed the lower ORR activities of Pd-N/C and Pt-N/C. Therefore, combined with the rotating ring-disk electrodes (RRDE) performances and theoretical studies, they concluded that the ORR activity of PM-SAC is positively related to the degree of match between the electronegativity (N, O) of the coordinating anions in the synthesized SAC and the noble metal atoms' ability to adsorb OH*. Based on this observation, they synthesized a highly loaded Ir-N/C (with loading of 4.5 wt%), which exhibited a high-power density of 870 mW cm−2 (O2) in PEMFC (Fig. 19b). Although PGM is currently the most effective catalyst for ORR, the high cost and scarcity of PGM have prompted researchers to develop more efficient and durable non-precious metal catalysts [224–226]. Among them, catalysts containing metal-N-doped carbon (MNC) active sites are considered promising alternatives to PGM [91,227,228]. MOF-derived SACs are an efficient solution that can provide abundant transition MNC active sites to improve the catalytic activity and selectivity of fuel cell cathodes [85,229,230]. Currently, MOF-derived PGM-free SACs have been reported and applied to the cathode of PEMFCs. Among the various kinds of non-precious metal catalysts, a large part of the efforts have been devoted to fabricating Fe-SAC since it exhibits excellent activity of ORR reaction [62,231,232]. With this context, Deng et al. [233] used ZIF-8 as a precursor, Fe acetylacetonate as an Fe source, and applied a g-C3N4 nitrogen fixation strategy to fabricate a Fe-SAC with impressive Fe loading of 3.17 wt%. The cathode fabricated from this catalyst exhibited extensive pH-independent durability and significant ORR activity in rotating disk measurements with a half-wave potential of 0.78 V in the acidic media and 0.845 V in the alkaline media. With a similar method, Shui’s group [234] synthesized a concave-shaped FeNC electrocatalyst by utilizing ferrous acetate (Fe(Ac)2) as the Fe source in combination with SiO2-coated ZIF-8 as the template (Fig. 19c). The anisotropic thermal shrinkage of ZIF-8 results in the formation of concave-shaped morphology, which is beneficial for achieving enhanced mesoporosity and external surface area of the catalyst. The active site of the Fe-SAC was determined by Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy and XAS, which reveals a possible structure of the FeN4C8 moiety with two O2 molecules adsorbed in end-on mode (Fig. 19d). This synthetic strategy maintained the basic structure of the ZIF-8 and effectively increased the specific surface area and active site density of the material. The Fe-N4 active site exhibits efficient mass transfer performance with a current density of 0.047 A cm−2 at 0.88 ViR-free at 1 bar H2-O2, which exceeds the Department of Energy (DOE) target in 2018 (0.044 A cm−2, 0.88 ViR-free), according to the U.S. DOE test protocol (Fig. 19e). Besides using Fe containing compounds as an iron source, some studies also reported the fabrication of Fe-SAC from Fe doped MOFs. For instance, Zhang et al. [235] designed a Fe-SAC with reasonable durability by controlling the Fe content through the chemical doping of Fe atoms in ZIF-8. Qiao et al. [236] constructed a Fe-SAC with an ordered porous structure of Fe-doped ZIF-8, which shows a half-wave potential of 0.80 V in strongly acidic media and only 20 mV lower than that of commercial Pt/C electrodes. Other than Zn-based MOF precursors (i.e., ZIF-8), another low boiling point metal of Cd-based MOF was also used as a precursor to fabricate Fe-SAC since high-temperature pyrolysis may lead to the formation of heterogeneous active moieties ranging from Fe single atoms to nanoparticles. For example, Al-Zoubi et al. [237] developed a ZIF-8 substitution of using Cd to replace Zn as the metal node since Cd has a lower boiling point than Zn. Then, the Cd-ZIF was used as a sacrificial template for further synthesis of Fe-SACs, which can effectively reduce the synthesis temperature of the MOF-derived SAC, which favorably preserved the monatomic Fe active site. In addition to Fe-SA-based catalysts, other non-precious metal catalysts have also been developed with good performances. For example, Wang et al. [238] synthesized Co-N4 catalytic centers by direct pyrolysis of ZIF-67 as a precursor. This catalyst achieved a half-wave potential of 0.80 V (vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE)) during ORR in acidic media, and the initial activity retention can reach 83% after 100 h at a relatively high potential (0.7 V) (Fig. 19f). Furthermore, Li et al. [239] developed a Mn-SAC with Mn-N4 active centers using a stepwise synthesis strategy of Mn-ZIF as a precursor. Experiments have shown that Mn-SAC (loading of 3.03 wt%) can withstand 3000 cycles of cyclic voltammetry (CV) test in a strongly acidic medium, achieving a stabilization time of 100 h. The DFT calculations further confirm that the Mn-N4 catalytic undergoes the 4 e− pathway ORR process in acidic media, effectively suppressing the side reaction of H2O2 generation during the ORR process (Fig. 19g). In contrast to constructing single metal catalysts, an Fe and Ni bimetallic catalyst (denoted as FeNi-N6) was also developed by Sun’s group with ZIF-8 derived porous N-doped carbon material as the support (Fig. 20 a and b) [240]. Notably, based on XANES fitting and DFT calculation, they concluded that the coordination structure of FeNi-N6 is that each metal atom coordinated with four N atoms instead of three, which is correlated with catalytic activity. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 20(c), a comparison of ORR curves of the cathodes containing Fe-N4 and FeNi-N6 catalytic centers is subjected to 5000 potential cycles in acidic media. The stability curves before and after potential cycling with the FeNi-N6 catalytic center showed almost no change, indicating that the introduction of Ni single atoms can improve the stability of the electrode. Even though the reported MOF-based SACs displayed good performance, however, some obstacles still inhibited their real application in PEMFCs, for example, the potential corrosion of MOF-derived carbon substrate owing to the acid and high-temperature working condition of PEMFCs, thus affecting the stability of the catalyst. In addition, the ORR performance of reported MOF-based PGM-free SACs is still much lower than that of commercialized Pt with similar loading. Developing catalysts with optimized activity centers and configuration is still a significant challenge. The ORR in alkaline media of AEMFC possesses high stability and reactivity, which enables SAC to be widely used in AEMFC with favorable reaction stability and catalytic activity [241–243]. Recently, Kang et al. [244] reported the first study on the application of MOF-derived SACs in AEMFCs. They fabricated a Fe-N4 catalyst using the electrostatic forces between negatively charged pyrrole-N and positively charged Fe ions (Fig. 20d and e). Compared to Fe-SAC directly derived from ZIF-8 (denoted as Fe/HCF with Fe loading of 1.14 wt%), the Fe-N4 site content was increased by pyrolysis of pyrrole-N-rich carbon (pNC)-encapsulated ZIF carriers (denoted as Fe/pNC@HCF with Fe loading of 1.34 wt%), owing to that the evenly coated pNCs with negative charge can be used as anchoring sites for Fe ions (Fig. 20f). The Fig. 20(g) shows the Tafel slope data of Fe/pNC@HCF and Fe/HCF to evaluate the ORR kinetic activity of the catalyst in alkaline electrolytes. The Fe/pNC SAC exhibited excellent ORR activity in alkaline media with Tafel slope of 68 mV dec−1, which is comparable to the commercial Pt/C catalysts (67 mV dec−1). As shown in Fig. 20(h), the membrane electrodes prepared with Fe/pNC@HCF exhibit a current density of 437 mA cm−2 and a power density of 343 mW cm−2 at 0.6 V, respectively, while the Fe/HCF electrode achieves only 82% of the Fe/pNC@HCF electrode performance. This study effectively demonstrated the potential application of Fe-SAC with high loading for AEMFCs. The studies of MOF-derived SACs in fuel cells are summarized in Table 1 . 6.2 Application in Zn-air batteries For Zn-air batteries, one of the main challenges is the high overpotential between the ORR and OER due to the slow chemical reaction kinetics in the air cathode, which can be improved by the introduction of SACs [245]. As reported by Chen et al. [62], a functionalized hollow Fe-SAC (Fe-SAs/NPS-HC) composite can effectively accelerate the ORR kinetics of the Zn-air battery. Compared to the commonly used Pt/C-based air cathode, the cell performances of the Fe-SAs/NPS-HC based one are obviously enhanced with higher open-circuit voltage (1.45 vs. 1.39 V), maximum power density (195.0 vs. 177.7 mW cm−2), and higher current density (375 vs. 283 mA cm−2). This research provides a viable case for developing a commercially available air cathode with wide versatility. In addition, the catalytic performances of SACs with different coordination configurations were studied. As reported by Hai and co-authors [246], by adjusting the ratio of N and C atoms in Co/Zn-ZIF@ZIF-67 precursors under different temperatures (i.e., 800, 900, and 1000 °C), three Co-SAC active centers with different NC structures (i.e., Co-N4, Co-N2C2, and Co-N3C1) were obtained. The catalytic principles of these structures are studied by DFT calculations (Fig. 21 a and b), which suggested that the ratio of N to C coordinated with the single Co site has a significant impact on the distribution of Co d states near-Fermi energy (EF) and Co-N3C1 shows the stronger hybridization between Co d and O2 2π* near EF than other two configurations. Thus, the Zn-air battery assembled by Co-N3C1 sites-based composite with Co loading of 2.1 wt% shows high durability for 5000 cycles and a small Tafel slope of 46 mV dec−1. Despite the normally applied coordination sites such as N, O, and S, the defect vacancy can also affect the SACs performances. A representative example was reported by Yang et al. [87]. They anchored Cu-SACs in a ZIF-8-derived carbon carrier by a gasification synthesis strategy (Fig. 21c and d). Although this high-temperature gasification synthesis strategy did not yield a high content of single-atom loading (Cu-SAC content of 0.45 wt%), the Cu-N3-V (V represents empty sites that are not involved in the coordination) active center shows a much lower theoretical ORR overpotential than Cu-N3 and the Cu-N3-C models, indicating the key role of a defect in the ORR catalysts. Thus, the Cu-N3-V catalyst enabled the cell to exhibit significant capacity (736 mA h g−1) and stability for 20,000 cycles ( Fig. 21e and f). In addition to synthesizing SACs in three-dimensional (3D) MOFs, Zou et al. [247] fabricated an ultrathin carbon nanoribbon (Fe-N/CNRib) with N-doped Fe single atom by facile direct pyrolysis of one-dimensional (1D) Fe-MOF nanorods. When used as the cathode of Zn-air batteries, this Fe-SAC shows stable charge/discharge potentials (1.96 and 1.14 V) with a voltage gap of only 0.82 V, which is better than the commercially available Pt/C&IrO2 electrode of 0.92 V, demonstrating its great potential for practical applications. Besides mono-metal SACs, researchers have also studied the performance of bimetallic SACs in Zn-air batteries [248,249]. The DFT calculations confirm that the multi-metal atomic synergistic catalyst with multiple coordination structures can optimize the adsorption strength of the active center and enhance the conversion efficiency of *OOH to accelerate the production of OH−, which is beneficial to the enhanced ORR activity. The flexible electronics with portability and wearability have received extensive attention for smart clothing, intelligent bracelets, and roll-up displays. As a flexible power supply device with relatively mature manufacturing methods and abundant reserves of zinc, Zn-air batteries are extensively used in wearable devices [152]. Zang et al. [250] reported the first study of applying the well-dispersed Co-SACs in a flexible Zn-air cell cathode without any binder or additives (Fig. 22 a). The Co-MOF-derived Co-SAC (Co loading of 1.84 wt%) greatly enhanced the ORR and OER performance with an OER overpotential as low as 360 mV and an ORR saturation current of 10.38 mA cm−2 at 0.6 V (vs. RHE), which is much larger than that of Pt/C (8.52 mA cm−2). Moreover, compared with the non-monoatomic dispersed Co catalyst, the Co-SAC air cathode shows a higher open-circuit voltage (1.411 V), higher maximum current density (31.0 vs. 24.7 mA cm−2), and peak power density (20.9 vs. 16.9 mW cm−3), suggesting that the Co SAC facilitates the oxygen adsorption and the subsequent OO bond breaking during the ORR reaction more effectively (Fig. 22b–d). Additionally, Ji et al. [149] synthesized an ORR/OER bifunctional Co-SAC (Co SA@NCF/CNF) through a novel synthetic strategy by using electro-spun nanofiber (ENF) and Co-ZIF as precursors (Fig. 22e). They demonstrated the application potential of this catalyst by using it as a working electrode to evaluate the OER performance in alkaline media. The polarization curve of the Co-SAC electrode showed a low overpotential of 400 mV at 10 mA cm−2, which was slightly inferior to that of the Ir/C electrode, confirming the effectiveness and excellent performance of Co-SAC. Due to the reported favorable performance of Co-SACs in Zn-air batteries, Han et al. [100] further verify its application in wearable energy storage devices. The atomic Co loading was optimized to 1.70 wt% by adjusting the Zn content in Zn/Co bimetallic-ZIF precursors. Then, they designed a flexible solid-state Zn-air battery constructed with a Zn foil anode, KOH-polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) electrolyte, and a Co-SAs@NC cathode supported by carbon cloth (Fig. 22f). This solid-state battery obtains an open-circuit voltage of 1.40 V, which is comparable to that in a liquid electrolyte. The electrostatic discharge-charge curve shows that the voltage plateau can be kept stable for 1000 min at 1 mA cm−2 and it remains stable for more than 700 min even when the current density is increased to 2 mA cm−2 (Fig. 22g), confirming the considerable flexibility of this battery. Recently, Huang’s group [251] fabricated a defect-rich single Fe site catalyst loaded on a hierarchical porous CN support (denoted as Fe1/d-CN) from a metal-organic compound (iron acetylacetonate) coated ZIF-8 precursors. The high Fe single-atom loading in the final material is 2.04 wt%. The 30,000 accelerated durability test (ADT) cycles suggest the effectiveness of this approach. Table 2 summarizes the studies of MOF-derived SAC in Zn-air batteries with good ORR performance and cycle stability. Nevertheless, for real applications, electrocatalyst poisoning during the reaction should also be considered. The strong absorption between the SAC surface and poisonous species will spoil the catalyst activity during the ORR process. In addition, the SACs fabricated from MOFs are compared by a concern to generate byproducts such as pure metal, metal-nitrogen coordinated with different numbers, or metal-carbon composites, which can also reduce the catalytic performance. Therefore, further exploration is needed to design anti-position and stable catalysts for Zn-air batteries. 6.3 Application in Li-based batteries The development of Li-based batteries is now showing a diversified trend, and the enthusiasm for their research comes mainly from industrial development [252]. To meet the growing energy storage needs of the society, developing the next-generation Li-based batteries with significantly improved performance is particularly important. In recent years, MOF-derived SACs have been favored for their excellent performance in Li-ion batteries (LIBs), Li-O2 batteries, and Li-chalcogen batteries. 6.3.1 Application in LIBs and Li-O2 batteries Li-ion batteries are commercialized in the market, however, the increasing energy demand in portable devices and electric vehicles still triggers the development of it [253–255]. Among all kinds of materials, silicon (Si) anode exhibits the highest theoretical capacity of 4200 mA h g−1 and a low Li-uptake potential of 0.4 V, which has been regarded as the most promising anode [256–259]. However, one instinct drawback of Si anode is the huge volume expansion during the lithiation and delithiation process (up to 300%), leading to the pulverization of the electrode and deteriorating the cycling performance. To solve this problem, very recently, Chen et al. [260] creatively reported a strategy of using ZIF-8 derived Zn-SAC (Zn loading is about 2.63 wt%) based nanoreactor to confine Si by in-situ reduction of SiH4 precursor (Fig. 23 a and b). With the help of MOF-derived Zn-SAC, where Zn atoms are well anchored in the rhombododecahedral structure, the Si nanodots are in situ formed and confined with a large amount (28.08 wt%). Such a unique nanoreactor shows excellent mechanical stability in encapsulating ultrasmall Si nanodots in the nanopores, thus inhibiting the volume change of Si with zero-strain properties since the expansion and contraction rate of the anode is as low as only 2.76% during cycling (Fig. 23c and d). Therefore, the Si-based LIB exhibits superior electrochemical performance with a high specific capacity of 1327 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles at 100 mA g−1 in half-cell and a high energy density of 366 Wh kg−1 after 300 cycles in a full cell. Moreover, to emphasize the role of Zn SAC, authors have prepared two control samples without Zn SAC and with Au SAC sputtered on the substrate surface. Accordingly, the obtained Si/C composites show low Si content and Si nanowires, respectively, with poor LIBs performances (Fig. 23f–j). This work provides a new application of SACs for batteries, which not only can accelerate the battery reactions but also can be used in the synthetic process to benefit for the redox reactions of active materials. Besides Li-ion batteries, the high oxygen accessibility, open metal sites, and high microporous surface area of MOF provide promising prospects for synthesizing efficient ORR catalysts in Li-O2 batteries [261–264]. On the one hand, MOF-derived carbon has a controllably large specific surface area, which facilitates the diffusion of O2 and Li+; on the other hand, heteroatoms (such as O, N) can also be introduced into MOF-derived carbon as additional metal coordination sites by pyrolysis, thus effectively combining the advantages of MOF and SACs [265]. Compared to 3D MOFs, two-dimensional (2D) MOFs possess more exposed active sites, a large specific surface area, and nanoscale thickness. Theoretically, anchoring single atoms in the carbon matrix derived from 2D MOFs can completely unleash their potential in catalytic activity and efficiency. Consequently, the prevailing approach is to use 2D MOFs as precursors for preparing high-performance ORR catalysts in Li-O2 batteries.
