A research on the application of MOFs-derived SACs to Li-O2 batteries was first reported in 2019 by Yin’s group [266]. They synthesized a SAC with an MOF mixture of MIL-100(Fe) and ZIF-8 (Fig. 23k). This synthetic strategy was to employ a combined carrier gas (N2 and NH3) for thermal treatment to obtain the Fe-Fe3C@Fe-N4-C catalytic active centers. Experimental data and free energy calculations indicate that the presence of Fe-Fe3C@Fe-N4-C active sites in this Fe-SAC enhanced the cathodic ORR reactivity (Fig. 23l). In particular, the combination of Fe-N4-C with Fe3C leads to an enhanced affinity for O atoms and desorption of *OH, which accelerates the kinetic process of ORR. Ultimately, the SAC decorated cathode exhibited a discharge capacity as high as 8749 mA h g−1 (Fig. 23m). Afterwards, Wang et al. [267] synthesized a material containing a large number of Co-N catalytic sites for cathode catalysis in Li-O2 batteries by using a 2D MOF. This 2D MOF was assembled using hexamethylenetetramine (HMT) and Zn(NO3)2∙9H2O by a gasification synthesis strategy. The experimental results show that these active sites (Co-SA/NC) favor the redox kinetics for the reactivity of ORR and OER and the generation/decomposition of LiO2. And the theoretical simulations confirmed that an abundance of Co-N4 active sites could significantly increase the intrinsic affinity of the cathode to active intermediate species, which fundamentally regulates the reaction conversion mechanism of Li2O2. The Co-N4 active sites significantly enhanced the decomposition kinetics of Li2O2 and restrained the side reaction of Li2O generation. Therefore, the obtained Li-O2 battery exhibits excellent performance with an ORR/OER overpotential of 0.97 V and a capacity of 1000 mA h g−1 for 260 cycles at 400 mA g−1. 6.3.2 Application in Li-chalcogen batteries As one of the most promising next-generation energy storage systems, Li-chalcogen batteries (i.e., Li-S batteries and Li-Se batteries) have attracted much attention from researchers due to their high theoretical capacity and relatively low cost. However, the slow transfer kinetics between Li polysulfide intermediates seriously affected its electrochemical performances. Recently, some studies have achieved noteworthy progress by utilizing MOF-derived SACs for Li-S batteries [268]. The pioneering example was reported by Wang et al. [148]. As displayed in Fig. 24 (a and b), they designed a Fe-coated porous N-rich carbonaceous cage (FeSA-CN) from ZIF-8 precursor and used it as a host for sulfur storage (S loading of 67.8 wt%). The CV curve of FeSA-CN/S shows two strong reduction peaks at 2.27 and 2.03 V, which is higher than that of CN/S at 2.25 V and 1.99 V (Fig. 24c), confirming that NaPSs possess faster chemical reaction kinetics on FeSA-CN/S electrodes. Consequently, the FeSA-CN/S electrode delivered a specific capacity of 605 mA h g−1 at 4 C with a capacity decay rate of 0.06% after 500 cycles. Similarly, Chen et al. [269] derived a Co-SAC for sulfur storage from the bimetallic MOF (Co1Zn1-BZIF) (Fig. 24d). The obtained Co-N4 moiety with Co loading of 0.66 wt% was used as a catalytic sulfur host (sulfur content of 76 wt%) for LSBs, which is actively towards the conversion between polysulfides and Li2S, effectively mitigating the shuttle effect. Thus, this cathode-based LSB exhibits exceptional cycling stability with a capacity of 737 mA h g−1 after 600 cycles at 1 C. In addition, Liu et al. [270] used the Mn-MOF as a precursor to prepare Mn-SACs by coordinating Mn atoms into O, N-doped hollow carbon spheres (Mn/C-(N, O)). The Mn atoms exhibit high catalytic activity for the conversion reaction of LiPSs, which is theoretically confirmed by DFT calculation with a strong binding energy of Mn/C-(N, O) to LiPSs. The abundant pores in the conductive carbon framework can facilitate the diffusion of electrolytes and promote the dynamic protection of the anode structure during cycling. As a result, such cathode exhibits excellent cycling stability with an initial capacity of about 900 mA h g−1 at 1 C and a capacity decay of only 0.05% per cycle after 1000 cycles. Recently, Li et al. [271] presented a strategy to synthesize Ni-SAC decorated mesoporous NC nanostructure (Ni-NC(p) (p represents porous structure)) from ZIF-8, which featured thin outer shells and porous inner networks as a multifunctional sulfur host for efficient Li-S batteries (Fig. 24f). They successfully embedded Ni monoatomic at the N coordination sites with Ni loading of 1.66 wt%. When used as a cathode for Li-S batteries, the Ni-NC(p) based cell exhibits excellent electrochemical properties with an average discharge capacity of 778.1 mA h g−1 at 1 C. When the current density of the Ni-NC(p)/S cathode recovers from 2 C to 0.1 C, its capacity recovers to about 87% of the initial capacity, showing a relatively stable rate performance, indicating the optimized electron/ion transport and chemical reaction kinetics of the electrode. Subsequently, they compared the cyclic charge and discharge voltage curves of the cells assembled with Ni-NC(p)/S, Ni-NC/S, and NC(p)/S (represents N-rich carbon/S) cathodes. In contrast, the cell with a Ni-NC(p)/S cathode having a single atomic Ni loading exhibits the lowest polarization overpotential (245.6 mV) in the charge/discharge curve at 1 C. In the cycle life test, the Ni-NC(p)/S cathode battery had a capacity retention rate of around 53% after 600 cycles. It is noteworthy that the structural characteristics and chemical state of the Ni single atoms in the Ni-NC(p)/S cathode remain essentially unchanged after the long-term cycling tests. The excellent performance of these MOF-derived SACs in Li-S batteries is proved to be a continuing stimulus for researchers to explore such materials. In addition to applying MOFs-derived SACs only to the cathode to alleviate the shuttle effect, some studies focus on the application of SACs in Li metal anode to inhibit the dendrite growth. This attempt provides a unique solution to improve the overall performance of the battery. As suggested by Shi et al. [91], excellent full-cell performances were achieved by utilizing a well-dispersed Zn atom-doped hollow carbon sphere (Zn1-HNC) as a bifunctional nanoreactor for an S storage cathode (Zn1-HNC-S) (S loading of 80%) and a dendrite-free Li anode (Zn1-HNC-Li) simultaneously (Fig. 25 a). The coordination configuration of Zn atoms in Zn1-HNC was identified as Zn-N4 based on the EXAFS fitting data. To investigate the adsorption and catalytic mechanism of LiPSs on the Zn1-HNC surface, they further employed the DFT calculations. As shown in Fig. 25(b), the free energy of S reduction by Zn1-HNC (0.58 eV) was much lower than that of HNC (0.83 eV), indicating more favorable thermodynamics of the S reduction reaction by Zn1-HNC. The Li2S decomposition energy barrier on the Zn1-HNC surface (1.62 eV) is much lower than that on the HNC (2.49 eV), suggesting that the Zn atoms can effectively catalyze the Li–S bond break to accelerate the reaction kinetics and the delithiation process. For the Li metal anode, the Zn single atom shows a Li adsorption energy of −2.04 eV, which is much higher than bare carbon with −0.48 eV, indicating Zn-SAC can provide sufficient sites for uniform Li nucleation. The ex-situ SEM images also confirm this theoretical conclusion, as depicted in Fig. 25(c–e), compared with Cu electrode with uneven deposition of Li dendrite, an ultrafine Li nucleation was realized in Zn-SAC-based anode. Therefore, when tested as a full battery, a superior cycling stability of 700 cycles at 5 C, a capacity decay of only 0.015% per cycle, and rate capability (989 mA h g−1 at 10 C) were obtained. Besides electrodes, SACs were also used to modify separators for Li-S batteries. A representative example was reported by Song et al. [272]. They designed a Janus separator by coating anionic Bio-MOF-100 ({[Zn8(ad)4(BPDC)6O2]·4Me2NH2} n ) and the derived Zn-SAC on each side of the polypropylene (PP) separator, which effectively inhibited the shuttle effect of LiPSs on the cathode and inhomogeneous deposition of Li+ on the anode (Fig. 25f). The Bio-MOF-100 is an ionic MOF with anion framework, which can induce Li+ to transfer along the MOF channels with a transfer number of 0.79. Moreover, the obtained Zn-SACs show a strong interaction with polysulfides, which is beneficial for the conversion reactions between LiPSs. Therefore, the assembled Li-S cells with a two-sides modified Janus separator exhibited an ultra-low polarization voltage of 52 mV and an ultra-long stability cycle of 2800 h even at 5 mA cm−2 and 10 mA h cm−2. Remarkably, the Janus separator effectively inhibited the growth of Li dendrites and the shuttle effect of polysulfides showing a 0.05% capacity decay rate at 2 C with 1000 cycles (Fig. 25g). Compared to S, Se owns similar chemical properties to S and is considered a more promising candidate for S, owing to its comparable theoretical volume capacity (3253 mA h cm−3) and stronger electrical conductivity than S (1 × 10−3 vs. 5 × 10−28 S m−1) [273–275]. The first application of MOF-derived SAC in Li-Se batteries was reported by Tian et al. [276]. They deposited the synthesized ZnCo-ZIF on the surface of polystyrene spheres (PS) particles and then obtained a C/Se composite (Se@CoSA-HC) with Co-SAC loading of 1.3 wt% and Se loading of 73 wt% (Fig. 26 a). The electrochemical performance demonstrated that this material exhibited an excellent rate capability of 311 mA h g−1 at 50 C and cycling stability with 267 mA h g−1 remaining after 5000 cycles (Fig. 26b). The decisive role of the chemical reaction during the discharge process was revealed in DFT calculations, which suggests that Co-NC site possesses a lower Gibbs free energy compared to NC site, thus beneficial for accelerating the reduction reaction of Se (Fig. 26c). Similarly, Cao et al. [277] recently prepared a ZIF-8-based hierarchical porous carbon host with binuclear monoatomic sites of Fe-N4 and Co2-N3 encased in a polydopamine (PDA) shell for Se storage (denoted as APPC/Se@PDA) (Fig. 26d). They employed a strategy of covering the carbon body with a PDA coating to give the enhanced structural stability with Se loading of 58 wt%. Subsequently, to theoretically evaluate the chemical absorption between different carbon substrates and selenium, they calculated the binding energy between carbon substrates and Se by DFT. In particular, the substrates containing binuclear monoatomic sites can provide a strong binding energy of 2.68 eV, which confirms the synergistic catalytic effect of single atom Fe and Co (Fig. 26e). The uniformly dispersed Fe and Co single-atom sites exhibit a synergistic effect that not only enhances the affinity between carbon and Se atoms but also improves the electron and Li+ transfer rates. The two cathodic peaks at 2.31 and 2.16 V in the CV test represent the irreversible transformation from solid Se8 to liquid LiPSes (Fig. 26f). Cycle testing of the cells showed that a capacity of 274 mA h g−1 was maintained even at a high current density of 23 C for 2500 cycles (Fig. 26g). In summary, MOF-derived SACs exhibit excellent potential for electrode materials and separators in Li-S/Se batteries to restrict the shuttle effect and enhance the redox reaction kinetics. The catalytic mechanism has been studied by theoretical calculations (such as absorption energy, Gibbs free energy, and transfer energy barriers) and experimental results. However, considering the practical applications, high areal sulfur/selenium loading is needed. The consequently thicker sulfur/selenium cathode will retard the mass transportation and phase transitions. Therefore, improving the catalytic efficiency of SACs is essential, requiring further development of MOF-derived SACs with higher SAC loading or enhanced SAC utilization. 6.4 Application in Na-based batteries The growing requirement for Li-based batteries leads to concern about economic sustainability owing to the low abundance and uneven distribution of lithium. Thus, Na-based batteries are considered a promising alternative technology due to the natural abundance of sodium (2.36 wt% in the earth’s crust) and the similar reaction mechanism of both kinds of batteries [278,279]. Generally, compared to other applications mentioned above, the studies for utilizing MOF-based SACs to improve the electrochemical performance of Na-based batteries (i.e., room-temperature (RT) Na-S and Na-Se batteries) are still at the starting stage and to the best of our knowledge, only three works have been reported. Analogous to Li-S batteries, RT Na-S batteries still suffer from poor conductivity of sulfur, the volume expansion of sulfur during cycling, the dissolution of sodium polysulfides, and the growth of dendrite on the Na side. One typical strategy to solve the issues mentioned above is encapsulating sulfur into a porous carbon host with high electronic conductivity and spatial space for sulfur storage. Furthermore, the structure features of MOF-derived carbon matrix perfectly fit these requirements. Moreover, introducing SACs to the cathode can effectively suppress the shuttle effect. Therefore, the MOF-derived SACs-based cathode in the RT Na-S battery shows superior properties. One representative example is given in Ref. [280]: starting from the Cu&Zn bimetallic MOF, a N-doped carbon host with Cu-SAC (denoted as Cu SA/NOC) was prepared for sulfur storage (Fig. 27 a). The Cu-SAC loading can reach up to 8.03 wt% by optimizing the Cu/Zn ratio in the Cu&Zn bimetallic MOF precursor. Interestingly, based on DFT calculation, the Cu SA/NOC host exhibits strong chemical affinity to S8, and thus weakens the SS bond in the S8 ring structure and promotes the ring opening reaction, which can be expressed by the equation of *S8→*S4+*S4 (Fig. 27b). This indicates that Cu single-atom can facilitate the conversion between NaPSs and S, thus improving the S utilization and rate performance of the cathode. When used as the cathode of RT Na-S batteries, it shows excellent performance with a reversible capacity of 601 mA h g−1 after 1000 cycles at 1 A g−1, and rate performance with 483 mA h g−1 at 5 A g−1. Besides monoatomic transition metal atoms, the feasibility of anchoring rare earth metals in MOFs has also been explored. Very recently, Zhang et al. [281] has prepared a sulfur host of Y single atoms anchored in ZIF-8-derived carbon support (denoted as Y SAs/NC) with a moiety of Y-N4 for RT Na-S batteries. Such Y SAs/NC (Y loading of 0.84 wt%) host exhibits sodiophilicity and sulfiphilicity properties, and it was used for sulfur and sodium storage to fabricate the high-performance Na-S full batteries (Fig. 27c). For the sulfur cathode, DFT calculations indicate that the single-atom Y site can effectively lower the decomposition energy barrier of Na2S and increase the kinetics of the reduction reaction of S8 to Na2S. For the sodium anode, the charge density difference analysis of adsorbed Na+ on NC and YN4/C indicates that the interaction between Na+ and YN4/C is stronger than that of NC, thus promoting the Na+ storage performance (Fig. 27d). As an element in the same group, Se exhibits similar properties to S with higher electronic conductivity [209]. In the Na-based battery test, the Se cathode still suffers from the shuttle effect of soluble MPSes and the effect of volume expansion during charging and discharging, resulting in low Se utilization. To enhance the Se utilization and cycling performance, MOF-derived SACs were also applied to Na-Se batteries. The pioneering work was reported recently in Ref. [282]: a N,O-codoped porous carbon host decorated with Ni single-atom catalyst (Ni SA/NOCs) was derived from the Ni&Zn-MOF for Se storage (Fig. 27e). The content of Ni-SAC reached up to 4.2 wt%. The electrocatalytic behavior of Ni-SAC was evaluated by DFT calculations. The calculated corresponding Gibbs free energies of sodium polyselenides conversion processes on Ni SA/NOCs and NOC (control sample) indicate the thermodynamically preferable reduction of Se on Ni SA/NOC. Moreover, the Na2Se decomposition energy barrier on Ni SA/NOC is lower than that on NOC, suggesting Ni-SA can promote the phase transformation of Na2Se, thus increasing the reaction kinetics. When used as a cathode for Na-Se batteries, the Ni-SAC-based cell shows excellent electrochemical performance with a high reversible specific capacity of 315 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.1 C, accompanied by a superior rate performance of 195 mA h g−1 at 5 C. Hitherto, MOF-derived SACs are widely recognized as the most promising representatives owing to their high performance and robust stability towards the Li/Na-based batteries, which are systematically summarized in Table 3 . 7 Conclusions and perspective SACs have shown great promise for their efficient atom utilization and unique reaction mechanism and are ideal candidates to bridge the gap between heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts. MOF-based SACs effectively integrate almost all the advantages of SAC and MOF, becoming a promising way to build SACs. So far, MOF-based SACs have been fabricated from two synthetic approaches, one is MOF-supported SACs and another one is MOF-derived SACs. The former approach has the following advantages: (i) the ordered multitopic organic metal-linkers and metal sites can provide abundant heteroatom anchor sites to coordinate with metal atoms to synthesize highly dispersed and highly loaded SACs; (ii) the highly tunable structure of MOF facilitates the fabrication of catalysts with desirable structures; (iii) the ordered structure of MOFs with multiple pores can facilitate the mass transfer of reactants to promote the catalytic reaction process. Another approach is to derive SACs from MOFs precursor, which not only inherits most of the structural features in the original MOF but also possesses superior electrical conductivity. In addition, MOFs can effectively improve the thermal stability and chemical stability of the carbonized carrier. Consequently, SACs prepared from MOF-derived carbon can exhibit superior performance in electrocatalysis. Meanwhile, evolving electron microscopy imaging and spectroscopic analysis techniques provide favorable evidence for identifying SACs. Synchrotron radiation-based XAS and in situ XPS measurements are widely used to identify catalyst structures and more information to understand the mechanism of specific catalytic reactions at the atomic scale. This review summarizes the recent research progress on applying MOF-derived SACs to various energy storage devices, including fuel cells, Zn-air batteries, Li-O2 batteries, LIBs, Li-S batteries, Li-Se batteries, Na-S batteries, and Na-Se batteries, confirming that MOF-derived SACs provide an ideal reaction platform for electrocatalytic reactions. However, despite the great progress, challenges such as enhancing catalyst stability, improving catalytic reaction activity, enhancing reaction selectivity, and deeply understanding the contribution of SACs in the catalytic reaction still need to be addressed. (1) Construction of high-performance SACs. Theoretically, the active site of a catalyst is composed of the metal center and its adjacent coordination atoms, which ultimately determine the selectivity and activity of the catalytic reaction. Therefore, precise tuning of the electronic structure of the coordination environment of metal atoms is essential for the performance of SACs. The reported strategies to improve the coordination environment of metal sites are mainly focused on doping heteroatoms (N, O) and constructing unsaturated coordination structures during the MOF derivatization process. It has been confirmed that enhancing the metal loading can effectively increase the density of active sites, but the metal aggregation phenomenon occurring when increasing the loading will affect the metal dispersion efficiency. Therefore, it is urgent to develop optimized MOF precursors with a large specific surface area and abundant ligand sites to construct high-performance SACs. (2) In-depth reaction mechanism studies. Despite the rapid development of current characterization techniques and computational strategies, obtaining accurate reaction mechanisms of catalytic processes is still complicated. Studies have confirmed that the active center in SAC changes unpredictably due to external conditions (e.g., temperature, pH) during the reaction process. The development of in situ characterization techniques (in situ HAADF-STEM, in situ XAS, in situ IR, and in situ XPS, etc.) has effectively solved the problems of dynamically monitoring the reaction mechanism of SAC active centers. Although in situ characterization techniques are not widely used due to the harsh conditions and high cost, they are irreplaceable for the in-depth and accurate understanding of detailed single-atom electronic structures, ligand environments and demonstrate the catalytic processes at important reaction sites more clearly. In addition, the combination of in situ characterization techniques and DFT calculations is also essential for revealing the reaction mechanism of SACs and improving the structural design of SACs. (3) Enhanced conductivity of MOFs. The application of MOF-supported SACs in electrochemistry is of great research value due to the abundant organic functional groups and metal sites in pristine MOFs that can provide potential reaction sites. However, MOF-supported SACs are mainly applied in gas-phase reactions and rarely studied directly in electrocatalysis fields due to the problem of poor conductivity. Improving the MOF conductivity is a key factor in breaking the bottleneck of such SAC applications. In general, MOF-derived SACs have shown impressive performance for energy storage devices. However, conflicts such as increasing metal monoatomic loading and maintaining catalyst stability still need to be resolved. Nevertheless, with reasonable optimization, the applications of MOF-based SACs in energy storage devices are sure to achieve more surprising results and the development of synthesis strategies for MOF-based SACs will undoubtedly be extended to a wider range of electrochemical research fields in the future. coredata.dc:description: The next-generation energy storage systems such as fuel cells, metal-air batteries, and alkali metal (Li, Na)-chalcogen (S, Se) batteries have received increasing attention owing to their high energy density and low cost. However, one of the main obstacles of these systems is the poor reaction kinetics in the involved chemical reactions. Therefore, it is essential to incorporate suitable and efficient catalysts into the cell. These years, single-atom catalysts (SACs) are emerging as a frontier in catalysis due to their maximum atom efficiency and unique reaction selectivity. For SACs fabrication, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been confirmed as promising templates or precursors due to their high metal loadings, structural adjustability, porosity, and tailorable catalytic site. In this review, we summarize effective strategies for fabricating SACs by MOFs with corresponding advanced characterization techniques and illustrate the key role of MOFs-based SACs in these batteries by explaining their reaction mechanisms and challenges. Finally, current applications, prospects, and opportunities for MOFs-based SACs in energy storage systems are discussed.
